observationText: Spred1+/- mice showed decreased learning and memory performance in the Morris water maze and visual-discrimination T-maze tests compared to wild-type littermates, indicating deficits in hippocampus-dependent learning.

Electrophysiological recordings on brain slices from Spred1+/- mice identified defects in short- and long-term synaptic plasticity in the hippocampal CA1 region, including impaired long-term potentiation (LTP) and enhanced long-term depression (LTD).
Biochemical analysis after LTP induction showed increased ERK-phosphorylation in hippocampal slices from Spred1+/- mice compared to wild-type, indicating hyperactivation of the Ras/ERK pathway.
Spred1+/- mice exhibited normal basic neuromotor abilities, sensory functions, and acute pain responses compared to wild-type littermates.

Spred1+/- mice performed significantly worse than wild-type littermates on the untrained transitive pair (AC) in the visual discrimination T-maze task, indicating impairment in higher-order relational memory.
Hippocampal slices from Spred1+/- mice showed lower fEPSP slopes at stronger stimulation intensities compared to wild-type, indicating reduced excitability.
Spred1+/- mice exhibited increased paired-pulse facilitation at 10 and 20 ms interpulse intervals in hippocampal slices compared to wild-type, suggesting altered presynaptic function.

Heterozygous Spred1+/- mice performed at an intermediate level between wild-type and Spred1-/- mice in the most difficult part of the T-maze visual discrimination task, suggesting they may experience slight hippocampus-dependent cognitive deficits.
Spred1+/- mice showed increased thigmotaxis (wall-hugging behavior) in the Morris water maze compared to wild-type littermates, indicating increased anxiety-like behavior.
